docs.lead_paragraph: The White House projected on Friday that the budget deficit would reach $445 billion in this fiscal year. That would make it by far the largest shortfall ever in the dollar amount, though it would be well below the record for a deficit as a percentage of the gross domestic product and well below the amount forecast six months ago.

headline.main: White House Says $445 Billion Deficit Forecast Isn't as Bad as It Looks

docs.snippet: The White House projected on Friday that the budget deficit would reach $445 billion in this fiscal year.    That would make it by far the largest shortfall ever in the dollar amount, though it would be well below the record for a deficit as a...

docs.lead_paragraph: A $345.5 million settlement by Schering-Plough yesterday to resolve a government Medicaid investigation provides a detailed glimpse into how drug companies can manipulate prices to overcharge state and federal programs. Government officials have taken a keen interest in how drug makers price and market their drugs in recent years, and the settlement is the latest in a series reached with large drug makers over accusations that they have overcharged Medicaid. Last year, Bayer paid $257 million and GlaxoSmithKline paid $86.7 million to settle similar allegations.

headline.main: Schering Case Demonstrates Manipulation Of Drug Prices

docs.abstract: $345.5 million settlement by Schering-Plough to resolve government Medicaid probe provides detailed glimpse into how drug companies can manipulate prices to overcharge state and federal programs; case centers around Schering-Plough offering insurers Cigna and PacifiCare Health Systems lower price for its allergy drug Claritin to prevent them from buying drug Allegra, and insurers wound up paying less than drug maker demanded from Medicaid; Federal law requires drug makers to offer their lowest prices to Medicaid; government's inquiry began six years ago after Schering-Plough employees Charles Alcorn, Beatrice Manning and Raymond Pironti Jr filed suit under private whistle-blower provision of federal False Claims Act; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A $345.5 million settlement by Schering-Plough yesterday to resolve a government Medicaid investigation provides a detailed glimpse into how drug companies can manipulate prices to overcharge state and federal programs.    Government officials have...

docs.lead_paragraph: He Just Wanted To Have Fun IF the secret to a successful convention speech is lowering expectations, then the Kerry campaign performed with diabolical brilliance Thursday.

headline.main: THE CONVENTION IN BOSTON; ADDRESSING THE CROWDS; Political Points

docs.snippet: He Just Wanted To Have Fun       IF the secret to a successful convention speech is lowering expectations, then the Kerry campaign performed with diabolical brilliance Thursday.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and JOHN TIERNEY

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush will begin a vigorous new phase of his re-election campaign on Friday, racing through the Midwest arguing that the nation has turned the corner in dealing with its problems and promising policy initiatives to help Americans deal with the strains of the 21st-century economy, his aides said Thursday. In a jab at his Democratic opponent, Senator John Kerry, Mr. Bush will call this phase of the campaign his ''Heart and Soul of America'' tour. The phrase alludes to Mr. Kerry's statement at a recent New York fund-raiser that the Hollywood entertainers who appeared there, some of whom made lewd or disparaging comments about Mr. Bush, represented the country's heart and soul.

headline.main: THE CONVENTION IN BOSTON: POINTS AND COUNTERPOINTS; THE PRESIDENT; As Democratic Gathering Wraps Up, Bush Is Raring to Go

docs.abstract: Pres Bush begins vigorous new phase of re-election campaign through Midwest, where he will argue that nation has turned corner in dealing with its problems and promise domestic policy initiatives; calls phase of campaign Heart and Soul of America tour; aides say he will deliver new stump speech; photos; maps show upcoming campaign stops by Bush and Sen John Kerry; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Night after night at the convention, speaker after speaker, the Democrats -- a group traditionally bearing the label ''big spenders'' -- have sought to turn the tables on President Bush by accusing him of being fiscally irresponsible. In his acceptance speech on Thursday, Senator John Kerry hammered this theme, asserting that the large budget deficits that have sprouted under Mr. Bush are a symbol of economic mismanagement. Mr. Kerry contrasted the vastly improved budgetary picture under Bill Clinton with the deficits under Mr. Bush and said, ''We can do better.''

headline.main: THE CONVENTION IN BOSTON: ADDRESSING THE CROWDS; ECONOMIC POLICY; Democrats Tag Bush, Not Them, as Reckless Spender

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry and other Democrats speaking at national convention hang mantle of big deficits and irresponsible spending on Pres Bush and Republicans; respondents in New York Times/CBS news poll say deficit is big problem (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Under the headline ''Voters Want Specifics From Kerry,'' The Washington Post recently quoted a voter demanding that John Kerry and John Edwards talk about ''what they plan on doing about health care for middle-income or lower-income people. I have to face the fact that I will never be able to have health insurance, the way things are now. And these millionaires don't seem to address that.'' Mr. Kerry proposes spending $650 billion extending health insurance to lower- and middle-income families. Whether you approve or not, you can't say he hasn't addressed the issue. Why hasn't this voter heard about it?
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says television news programs, source of news for four out of five Americans, no longer report candidates' policies, focusing instead on trivia that supposedly reveal their personalities; says campaign coverage as celebrity profiling has no rules, offering ample scope for biased reporting; says failure of TV news to inform public about policy proposals of this year's presidential candidates is, in its own way, as serious a journalistic betrayal as its failure to raise questions about rush to invade Iraq (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In their first three weeks of using Nassau County's new drug discount card, residents have filled more than 5,000 prescriptions with average savings of $17.86 per order, or 24 percent, county officials said yesterday. The NassauRx cards were mailed to 500,000 homes about a month ago, and their use has grown steadily since, the officials said.

headline.main: Officials Say Prescription Cards Are Just What Nassau Ordered

docs.abstract: Nassau County, NY, residents have filled more than 5,000 prescriptions with average savings of $17.86, or 24 percent, using new drug discount cards issued free to all county residents; customer reaction is positive although there is some confusion about eligibility (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rehabilitating The L-word Call it the Night of the Piranha -- the smiling piranha. Trial lawyers were practically giddy on Wednesday as one of their own, Senator John Edwards, became the Democratic vice presidential nominee. As Mr. Edwards himself said over and over, ''Hope is on the way.''

byline.original: By JOHN TIERNEY and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: The last time John Kerry gave a speech this important, he was 27 years old and testifying against the Vietnam War. He sought help from Robert F. Kennedy's speechwriter and stayed up all night tinkering with his text. And he was a smash. On Thursday night Mr. Kerry will reclaim the nation's attention when he accepts his party's nomination for president. He has spent weeks drafting and rewriting his speech in a longhand few aides can decipher, and has turned for help to two of John F. Kennedy's best-known speechwriters -- Theodore C. Sorensen and Richard N. Goodwin -- while relying more heavily on his top consultant, Robert Shrum, the author of Senator Edward M. Kennedy's most celebrated oratory.

headline.main: THE CONVENTION IN BOSTON -- THE SPEECH; Any Kennedy Touches Won't Be Coincidental

docs.abstract: Speculation about Sen John Kerry's acceptance speech at Democratic convention; advisers say he will target unpersuaded voters, letting them know he will be more effective commander in chief and more trustworthy leader than Pres Bush; he must also find way to excite party faithful and connect with viewers who do not have clear sense of who he is; speech is said to be highly personal effort; some tips from some prominent public speakers discussed (M)
